They’ve just changed the rule. -Not the best medical benefits. -I used to work for Corporate and things tend to be very efficient. With Sanger, people tends to be very reluctant to changes, spend more time messing around than actual doing work. Things are very chaotic. It’s probably the most inefficient company I’ve ever worked for. -Senior manager or executives are a bit of a joke. They don’t listen to the people rather they rule like dictators. They were also accused of sexism a while ago. It’s was on the news. -They usually promote senior managers within and very reluctant to bring in outsiders who has real experience. You get the most inefficient people. -They’re using obsolete technologies. -Those who work for a long time for Sanger will have a hard time finding job working for really industries. I tend not to give bad reviews but this company is one of the worst of the worst.

pros: The institute has nice grounds, a good restaurant and gym.  It is also well funded (although for how much longer?) which means that you can usually get the equipment that you need.
cons:
Under the CEO's direction the institute is returning to it's roots of sequencing and pretty much nothing else.  It's a shame since a lot of the transnational science that we had been doing was pretty interesting, but perhaps we were getting too diverse.  That said, the rationalisation has been handled very badly, with lots of disgruntled staff being released into the local community and many negative stories in the national press and on social media.
Sanger has always preferred to appoint from within (perhaps part of the above problem?) and has made some frankly bizarre internal appointments recently. 
 Perhaps this is  because our poor reputation locally has made it difficult to recruit decent candidates, but the recent appointment at the very top of scientific operation by the executive has left many people frankly gobsmacked and has led to even more high profile departures.  A real case of 'the inept appointing the incompetent'  as one observer put it.

Cambridge is a very expensive city and there are plenty of high-tech companies in the area, so 38k isn't going to attract the top talent. review_title: Good place to work for a few yrs to launch career, terrible for long term prospects
pros:
1) Work life balance is for the most part good, but it does depend on which team you are in.   Talk to the team members during your interview.

2) Free bus service (mainly from Cambridge only)

3) On-site gym/social activities 

4) Promotes diversity, Women in Science/LGBT etc.

5) Science at scale!!! There are very few other places that have the capability to do this.

6) Amazing support and social retreats/activities for graduate students and postdocs.  Not so much for general staff.
cons:
1) Career progression is non-existent (A good place to be for 2-3 yrs only, publish then leave and leverage the "Sanger brand" elsewhere). 

2) Cambridge is a very expensive place to live, and places that are cheaper like Royston or Haverhill, are not serviced by the campus bus service.  There is also poor public transit links to the site.  

3) Salaries are great for those starting a phd or postdocs, probably one of the best in the region, but for everyone else it is simply not competitive enough.  Bioinformaticians & software developers simply walk across the pavement to the neighboring institute, EBI or to the many new startup companies setting up on site, where salaries and benefits are significantly better.  This sometimes feels like the norm.  Sanger simply has no real plan for retention, especially for high performers (seems to apply to senior employees as well) and appears to have accepted this fact.  

If you are a manager, having high staff turnover is horrible and very disruptive to work timelines and team morale.  
However if you are staff, as long as you accept that working at Sanger is a short term endeavor with the goal of name dropping it on to your CV, then its not a bad place to be, otherwise the life science/tech landscape in Cambridge area is very strong, and there are many better places to build a long term career at, that is both mentally stimulating and financially rewarding.
